domanda: In computing virtualization, the Trap-And-Emulate approach:

opzioneB: Is used only to intercept privileged CPU instructions.
opzioneC: Is used only to intercept system calls.
opzioneD: Can be used to emulate all the instructions that generate a trap.
motivazione: Trap-and-Emulate relies on the hardware generating a trap (exception) when a privileged instruction is executed by the Guest. The hypervisor catches this trap and emulates the instruction. If an instruction generates a trap, it can be handled this way.

domanda: CPU para-virtualization:
opzioneA: Replaces some source code of the GuestOS kernel with the proper equivalent function in the HostOS kernel.
opzioneB: Replaces system calls with an equivalent function of the GuestOS kernel.
opzioneC: Replaces system calls with an equivalent function of the HostOS kernel.
opzioneD: Replaces some binary code of the GuestOS kernel with the proper equivalent function in the HostOS kernel.
motivazione: Paravirtualization involves modifying the Guest OS source code. Instead of executing sensitive instructions that would trap, the Guest uses "hypercalls" to explicitly request operations from the Hypervisor.

domanda: Modern CPUs:
opzioneA: Have many CPU rings, and N of them are intended for executing OS kernels (where N can be dynamically programmed).
opzioneB: Have 8 CPU rings, but we can use only 4 of them at each time.
opzioneC: Have many CPU rings, and 2 of them are intended for executing OS kernels.
opzioneD: Have 8 CPU rings (from least to most privileged)
motivazione: With hardware virtualization extensions (like Intel VT-x), we have Root Mode (Host) and Non-Root Mode (Guest). Both have Ring 0. Thus, there are 2 Rings intended for kernels (Host Ring 0 and Guest Ring 0).

domanda: Dynamic binary translation:
opzioneA: Always refers to an instruction executed by the HostOS kernel.
opzioneB: Can refer to an instruction executed by GuestOS kernel.
opzioneC: Always refers to an instruction executed by userland applications.
opzioneD: Always refers to an instruction executed by the GuestOS kernel.
motivazione: Binary Translation is a technique where the hypervisor inspects Guest OS kernel code at runtime and replaces unsafe/sensitive instructions with safe blocks of code to avoid traps.

domanda: In a virtualized system, VMEntry and VMExit instructions:

opzioneB: Are almost equivalent to the Trap-And-Emulate approach.
opzioneC: Enable fast transitions between GuestOS and HostOS kernels.
opzioneD: Enable fast transitions between userspace and HostOS kernel.
motivazione: VMEntry and VMExit are specific hardware instructions provided by virtualization extensions (like VMX) to switch context between the Hypervisor (Host/Root) and the VM (Guest/Non-Root).

domanda: In computing virtualization, a hypervisor:

motivazione: Emulating exact physical hardware (registers, electrical behavior) is computationally expensive. Hypervisors typically emulate only a small set of generic devices, relying on paravirtualization (VirtIO) for the rest.
